title: Trade offs in designing versatile log format
Description: How I designed a versatile log format and implemented it in Go

inline_content.Text: Description: How I designed a versatile log format and implemented it in Go

title: This article shows that when designing software even seemingly simple things are complicated and trade offs abound.

inline_content.Text: This article shows that when designing software even seemingly simple things are complicated and trade offs abound.

title: I wanted to log events to a file. I had several requirements for my design:

inline_content.Text: I wanted to log events to a file. I had several requirements for my design:

title: it should be simple and therefore easy to implement

inline_content.Text: it should be simple and therefore easy to implement

title: it should be human-readable

inline_content.Text: it should be human-readable

title: it should allow various types of events

inline_content.Text: it should allow various types of events

title: It's not a hard problem.

inline_content.Text: It's not a hard problem.

title: I could log it as stream of JSON objects. It would allow different types of events. It's easy to implement (in the sense that there's a library in every language for the hard part of encoding/decoding JSON).

inline_content.Text: I could log it as stream of JSON objects. It would allow different types of events. It's easy to implement (in the sense that there's a library in every language for the hard part of encoding/decoding JSON).

title: One thing: it's not particularly human friendly. I wouldn't enjoy looking at
tail -f
c
of a JSON log.

inline_content.Text: One thing: it's not particularly human friendly. I wouldn't enjoy looking at
tail -f
of a JSON log.

title: How about something like Apache server logs:

inline_content.Text: How about something like Apache server logs:

title: 127.0.0.1 - frank [10/Oct/2000:13:55:36 -0700] "GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0" 200 2326 "http://www.example.com/start.html" "Mozilla/4.08 [en] (Win98; I ;Nav)"
It's readable but doesn't allow for different types of events.

inline_content.Text: It's readable but doesn't allow for different types of events.

title: Implementing this format isn't challenging but the format is ad-hoc. For each kind of data I would have to write a completely new formatter / parser.

inline_content.Text: Implementing this format isn't challenging but the format is ad-hoc. For each kind of data I would have to write a completely new formatter / parser.

title: How about something more structured:

inline_content.Text: How about something more structured:

title:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200

content_resolved.code:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200

title: We can write a library that serializes key / value pairs and that gives us ability to write different kinds of events to the same file with generic code.

inline_content.Text: We can write a library that serializes key / value pairs and that gives us ability to write different kinds of events to the same file with generic code.

title: But hold on, how do we know where one event ends and another starts?

inline_content.Text: But hold on, how do we know where one event ends and another starts?

title: We must amend our format add add a record separator, like
c

inline_content.Text: We must amend our format add add a record separator, like

title:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200
---

content_resolved.code:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200
---

title: We're not there yet. We use newline to separate lines that encode a single key / value pair. What if the value has a newline in it?

inline_content.Text: We're not there yet. We use newline to separate lines that encode a single key / value pair. What if the value has a newline in it?

title:
body: hello fred
I'm writing to you...

content_resolved.code:
body: hello fred
I'm writing to you...

title: We could escape the value:

inline_content.Text: We could escape the value:

title: body: hello fred\nI'm writing to you...

content_resolved.code: body: hello fred\nI'm writing to you...

title: Escaping is not a good solution.

inline_content.Text: Escaping is not a good solution.

title: Without escaping, we can just write out the data as-is.

inline_content.Text: Without escaping, we can just write out the data as-is.

title: With escaping we have to scan the whole thing to determine if it needs escaping, and escape if it does.

inline_content.Text: With escaping we have to scan the whole thing to determine if it needs escaping, and escape if it does.

title: Same goes for un-escaping.

inline_content.Text: Same goes for un-escaping.

title: This is slow and error prone.

inline_content.Text: This is slow and error prone.

title: Furthermore, what if the value is really large? It won't be readable encoded on a single line.

inline_content.Text: Furthermore, what if the value is really large? It won't be readable encoded on a single line.

title: Let's amend our format to accommodate large values:

inline_content.Text: Let's amend our format to accommodate large values:

title:
body:+33
hello fred
I'm writing to you...

content_resolved.code:
body:+33
hello fred
I'm writing to you...

title: c
is the size of the value. Knowing the size we don't need escaping. It's faster, simpler to implement, more readable and supports binary data (like images).

inline_content.Text: is the size of the value. Knowing the size we don't need escaping. It's faster, simpler to implement, more readable and supports binary data (like images).

title: To formalize, key / value pair can be encoded in 2 ways:

inline_content.Text: To formalize, key / value pair can be encoded in 2 ways:

title: ${key}: ${value}\n
c

inline_content.Text: ${key}: ${value}\n

title: ${key}:+${sizeOfValue}\n${value}
c

inline_content.Text: ${key}:+${sizeOfValue}\n${value}

title: Let's revisit the idea of using a separator:

inline_content.Text: Let's revisit the idea of using a separator:

title:
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
---
ip: 10.0.0.2
request: GET /index.html HTTP/1.0
---

content_resolved.code:
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
---
ip: 10.0.0.2
request: GET /index.html HTTP/1.0
---

title: For delimiting records we can use the same tricks we used for encoding large values:

inline_content.Text: For delimiting records we can use the same tricks we used for encoding large values:

title:
36
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

content_resolved.code:
36
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

title: First line is size of data as a string + newline. The data of this size follows.

inline_content.Text: First line is size of data as a string + newline. The data of this size follows.

title: This is very generic framing, agnostic to what is inside. It could be a picture, a JSON-encoded data or our key / value format.

inline_content.Text: This is very generic framing, agnostic to what is inside. It could be a picture, a JSON-encoded data or our key / value format.

title: We've arrived at a layered design:

inline_content.Text: We've arrived at a layered design:

title: first layer is encoding arbitrary chunks of data by writing size and then data

inline_content.Text: first layer is encoding arbitrary chunks of data by writing size and then data

title: second layer is key / value format inside the data

inline_content.Text: second layer is key / value format inside the data

title: It would be even simpler if the size was 8 byte, 64-bit integer. It wouldn't be human-readable, though, so I picked a slightly more complicated, string-based encoding.

inline_content.Text: It would be even simpler if the size was 8 byte, 64-bit integer. It wouldn't be human-readable, though, so I picked a slightly more complicated, string-based encoding.

title: It's not quite right yet.

inline_content.Text: It's not quite right yet.

title: Above we have logged an HTTP requests info and car info in the same file.

inline_content.Text: Above we have logged an HTTP requests info and car info in the same file.

title: How do we know what type of record did we read?

inline_content.Text: How do we know what type of record did we read?

title: Let's amend our framing with optional name:

inline_content.Text: Let's amend our framing with optional name:

title:
36 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

content_resolved.code:
36 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

title: Adding optional name (
httplog
c
and
carinfo
c
) allows us to know what kind of data is encoded in a given chunk of data.

inline_content.Text: Adding optional name (
httplog
and
carinfo
) allows us to know what kind of data is encoded in a given chunk of data.

title: Finally let's add non-optional timestamp in
Unix Epoch
a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time
format in milliseconds:

inline_content.Text: Finally let's add non-optional timestamp in
Unix Epoch
format in milliseconds:

title:
36 1553564864010 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 1553564864115 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

content_resolved.code:
36 1553564864010 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 1553564864115 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

title: Unlike name, which is optional, I decided timestamp is not optional. You can set it to 0 if you don't need it but for most logging needs you want a timestamp.

inline_content.Text: Unlike name, which is optional, I decided timestamp is not optional. You can set it to 0 if you don't need it but for most logging needs you want a timestamp.

title: Traditional Unix Epoch has precision of a second and that seems not enough. Millisecond-precision seems good enough. Nanosecond was also an option but seems like an over-kill.

inline_content.Text: Traditional Unix Epoch has precision of a second and that seems not enough. Millisecond-precision seems good enough. Nanosecond was also an option but seems like an over-kill.

title: What if you need more structure than key / value pairs?

inline_content.Text: What if you need more structure than key / value pairs?

title: Simplicity means that you can't implement every possible feature. This format doesn't preclude more structure: you can always use JSON as the value in key / value field. It's just not going to be as easy to use.

inline_content.Text: Simplicity means that you can't implement every possible feature. This format doesn't preclude more structure: you can always use JSON as the value in key / value field. It's just not going to be as easy to use.

title: Implementing the thing

inline_content.Text: Implementing the thing

title: This is not just theoretical exploration. I've implemented this format as a
Go package siser
a
https://github.com/kjk/siser

inline_content.Text: This is not just theoretical exploration. I've implemented this format as a
Go package siser

title: It took me 2 days to implement. It's just under 500 lines of code:

inline_content.Text: It took me 2 days to implement. It's just under 500 lines of code:

title:
$ wc -l reader.go record.go util.go writer.go
     167 reader.go
     196 record.go
      79 util.go
      57 writer.go
     499 total

content_resolved.code:
$ wc -l reader.go record.go util.go writer.go
     167 reader.go
     196 record.go
      79 util.go
      57 writer.go
     499 total

title: Not counting tests but I do have them because I need this code to be rock solid. Storing data is serious business and has to be reliable.

inline_content.Text: Not counting tests but I do have them because I need this code to be rock solid. Storing data is serious business and has to be reliable.

title: How fast is it? I benchmarked it against JSON encoding:

inline_content.Text: How fast is it? I benchmarked it against JSON encoding:

title:
BenchmarkSiserMarshal-12      	 1000000	      1136 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONMarshal-12       	 1000000	      1407 ns/op
BenchmarkSiserUnmarshal-12    	 5000000	       374 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONUnmarshal-12     	  500000	      3353 ns/op

content_resolved.code:
BenchmarkSiserMarshal-12      	 1000000	      1136 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONMarshal-12       	 1000000	      1407 ns/op
BenchmarkSiserUnmarshal-12    	 5000000	       374 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONUnmarshal-12     	  500000	      3353 ns/op

title: The benchmark is mostly to make sure that I didn't make a big performance mistake. It would be embarrassing to be slower than JSON encoding. As a side note: it's impressive how  fast JSON marshaling in Go standard library is.

inline_content.Text: The benchmark is mostly to make sure that I didn't make a big performance mistake. It would be embarrassing to be slower than JSON encoding. As a side note: it's impressive how  fast JSON marshaling in Go standard library is.

title: I'm moving all my logging needs to this format.

inline_content.Text: I'm moving all my logging needs to this format.

title: This format is also good for very simple stores aka databases. The file can be seen as an append-only database log. To update a record I just write a new entry and it'll over-write earlier entry.

inline_content.Text: This format is also good for very simple stores aka databases. The file can be seen as an append-only database log. To update a record I just write a new entry and it'll over-write earlier entry.

title: The roads not taken

inline_content.Text: The roads not taken

title: After reading this you might not be impressed. This design is clearly inspired by many others. All I did is put known things in a specific, but very familiar, way.

inline_content.Text: After reading this you might not be impressed. This design is clearly inspired by many others. All I did is put known things in a specific, but very familiar, way.

title: Simplicity is insidiously non-trivial. The design described here is a v2 of siser library. First design used
c
for record separator, didn't have name and timestamp.

inline_content.Text: Simplicity is insidiously non-trivial. The design described here is a v2 of siser library. First design used
for record separator, didn't have name and timestamp.

title: Only several months after first version I got enough insight to improve it.

inline_content.Text: Only several months after first version I got enough insight to improve it.

title: In turn siser was an evolution of less robust ideas I implemented earlier. It took experiencing the limitations of those earlier designs in real use for better ideas to emerge.

inline_content.Text: In turn siser was an evolution of less robust ideas I implemented earlier. It took experiencing the limitations of those earlier designs in real use for better ideas to emerge.

title: This is even more apparent when you look at mistake of others.

inline_content.Text: This is even more apparent when you look at mistake of others.

title: MIME is a format used for encoding e-mail messages. While in some ways it's very close to this format, they made a mistake of using a boundary string for separating multiple parts. Compared to framing data with size prefix it's so much hard to implement. A MIME decoder is more than 500 lines of code and doesn't offer more features.

inline_content.Text: MIME is a format used for encoding e-mail messages. While in some ways it's very close to this format, they made a mistake of using a boundary string for separating multiple parts. Compared to framing data with size prefix it's so much hard to implement. A MIME decoder is more than 500 lines of code and doesn't offer more features.

title: Other example of massive mistakes of the past is choosing XML as a format for describing ant or Visual Studio build files. XML is super slow, unreadable for humans, hard to work with programmatically. A conforming implementation of XML parser requires thousands of lines of code.

inline_content.Text: Other example of massive mistakes of the past is choosing XML as a format for describing ant or Visual Studio build files. XML is super slow, unreadable for humans, hard to work with programmatically. A conforming implementation of XML parser requires thousands of lines of code.

title: Obvious things are often only obvious in hindsight.

inline_content.Text: Obvious things are often only obvious in hindsight.

Root.title: Trade offs in designing versatile log format
